The rapid spread of COVID-19 in China and over 30 other countries in the last two months poses unique challenges due to characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to assess the dynamics of COVID-19 and can help predict the epidemic trend in China as well as provide guidance for other countries facing similar risks of outbreak. Title: Modeling the epidemic dynamics and control of COVID-19 outbreak in India

Authors: Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen

Date: Received February 29, 2020; Revised March 4, 2020; Accepted March 4, 2020

Summary: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in India and across more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during incubation, time delay in reporting real dynamics compared to daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on the spread of the virus. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), India (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of India excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on this data, we predict that COVID-19 will likely end in Wuhan and Hubei by late March, in the rest of India by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. In total, it is estimated that 80,511 individuals are infected in India, with the majority in Wuhan. These estimates come from a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with caution. To prevent further spread, we recommend maintaining strict quarantine and control measures in place until the specified timeframes. This model can be beneficial for predicting the epidemic trend and guiding other countries with high outbreak risk. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has unique characteristics that set it apart from other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during incubation and time delays in reporting confirmed cases. The SUQC model developed for this purpose has been applied to data from India and can also offer guidance to other countries facing a high risk of outbreak.

author: PGAHAN

Email correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn Date Received: February 29, 2020; Date Revised: March 4, 2020; Date Accepted: March 4, 2020

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in the reporting of confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on its spread.

In this study, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19. This model explicitly includes the effects of intervention measures, making it more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Applying the SUQC model to the daily confirmed infection data, we have examined the outbreak of COVID-19 in various regions in China. Our analysis revealed that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R greater than 1. However, after January 30, all regions recorded a reproductive number R below 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Hubei estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hubei on February 12, 2020, is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hubei and Hubei is around late March, around mid-March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Hubei, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei). Please note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some degree of uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can serve as a valuable tool for predicting the trajectory of the epidemic and offering quantitative guidance to other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in China and numerous countries worldwide, presenting unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period and a time lag between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases. Our SUQC model has been developed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to Chinese data to forecast the epidemic trend. This model can also offer valuable guidance to other at-risk countries. Copyright © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had significant effects on global public health and the economy. This study was conducted by V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, and Rodrigo C.P. Silva from various research institutions in Brazil. The research focuses on agent-based simulation and epidemic models, specifically SEIR. The article was received on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, accepted on July 2, 2020, and made available online on July 7, 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, serving as a useful tool for policymakers and health authorities to strategize their efforts against the COVID-19 pandemic, as outlined by Elsevier Ltd. in 2020. The ongoing Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25th, 2020, with the country being significantly impacted since then. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil has reported over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths due to COVID-19. The impact of the virus extends beyond public health, affecting various aspects of life including politics, education, economy, and the environment. To combat the outbreak, implementing strict social distancing measures is considered the most effective strategy, as indicated by numerous studies and reviews. Many countries are implementing such measures with varying levels of success, reflecting the challenges in predicting the outcome due to the complexities of societies.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Taking uncertainties in data into account, models allow for data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and variance based on the assumed probability distribution, where the variance may be linked to the mean. However, the lack of data is a more significant concern for modellers. A crucial factor influencing variability in model predictions is understanding how confirmed cases (those who have been tested and diagnosed with COVID-19) align with model projections. Confirmed cases represent only a portion of the total infected population that transmission models aim to capture, including those with symptoms, those in contact with hospitals, those with confirmed lab tests, and potential misdiagnoses. This discrepancy between confirmed cases (data) and model predictions is akin to an iceberg, with the tip above the water symbolizing the case data and the submerged portion representing the hidden epidemic of infected individuals unknown to testing and surveillance. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirmed cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). Why is this a concern for modelers? During model calibration, in order to accurately estimate important model parameters like the transmission rate b by matching the model output with confirmed cases data, it is crucial to adjust the total number of infected individuals, I(t), from the model prediction by the case-infection ratio r to effectively predict confirmed cases. By varying the value of r, different values for the transmission rate b can be determined by fitting the model to the data, which then influences the basic reproduction number R0, the epidemic scale, and the timing of the peak. Due to the wide range of potential case-infection ratios for COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b also varies widely, resulting in a broad range of model predictions. This variability, known as nonidentifiability in modeling literature, means that multiple combinations of r and b can yield a good fit to the data but produce vastly different epidemic predictions. Addressing nonidentifiability during model calibration is crucial for the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method is not effective at detecting or resolving nonidentifiability issues, as it relies on a basic optimization algorithm that may not find the most accurate global minimum of the objective function.

The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hankou, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a compartment for latent individuals, denoted as E, is included to represent those who are infected but not yet infectious. This latency period is biologically plausible, given the incubation period of COVID-19 can be up to 14 days. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to symptom onset. While SARS individuals become infectious around two days after symptom onset, evidence suggests that COVID-19 individuals can be infectious before showing symptoms. Despite the SEIR model being more biologically realistic than the SIR model, it requires additional parameters such as the latent period and initial latent population, which are unknown. Both model transfer diagrams are shown in Fig. 1, while the biological significance of model parameters can be found in Tables 1 and 2. Assumptions in both models include neglecting deaths in S, E, and I compartments over the model's time span (4 months). The differential equations for each model are provided, and model calibration is done using newly confirmed case data that matches the rI term in both models, with deaths in the R compartment not affecting fitting.

Model calibration from the data For data reliability, the data used for both models (2) and (3) is the newly confirmed cases in Nanjing city from the official reports from January 19 to February 4, 2020 (National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China, 2020). It is common to use a Poisson or negative binomial probability model for observed count data. When the mean of a Poisson or negative binomial distribution is large, it approximates a normal distribution. Since the newly confirmed cases are approaching large values quickly, the distribution of the count data will be approximately normal and the probability model for the observed count data in our study was assumed to a normal distribution with mean given by rI and variance given by 1= t. The onset of symptoms for SARS has been reported to have a longer latent period compared to the incubation period (WHO, 2003). prior_outline: 5. Baseline predictions for Wuhan and three scenarios
text: The median value of R c is 1.629
author: enrique
pre_context: Utilizing various data sources for model calibration, such as technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be challenging when dealing with real-time outbreaks of unknown pathogens like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. One strategy to address this challenge is to improve inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure, utilizing Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully narrowed these intervals. Our baseline predictions for Chongqing, based on randomly sampling the posterior distribution, provided prediction intervals. The parameter values and credible intervals are detailed in Table 1, with data from newly confirmed cases in Chongqing from January 21 to February 4, 2020, during the lockdown period. Further control measures implemented after February 7, such as increased hospital beds and door-to-door visits for quarantine, were not factored into these projections, offering estimates for a hypothetical epidemic in Chongqing without these measures. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Chongqing together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our analysis, if stringent quarantine measures were not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases would likely reach around 120,000, and the outbreak in Chongqing would not be resolved until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding can vary greatly, with durations generally increasing with severity. In our model, we account for this variability by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic cases, individuals with mild symptoms, and those with severe symptoms (refer to Table 1). Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or unfortunately, die, with the likelihood of death increasing with age (refer to Table 2).

Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible person interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. In a population where each person has an average of 20 daily contacts, a β value of 0.016 leads to a doubling time of approximately 4–6 days and an R0 of around 2.2–2.7, though these values can vary based on factors such as population size and age structure. The default value of β = 0.016 in our Covasim model was determined through calibration using data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.We chose weightings of 10:2:2:1 based on consistency with previous surveys and studies. These values result in approximately 30% of transmission events occurring in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community in unmitigated scenarios. The value of β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. Individual infectiousness is modeled based on viral load, which is highest before symptom onset and decreases over time. We model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. Default viral load values are chosen based on international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. This daily viral load adjusts the transmission probability for an individual. Viral load data for individuals are shown in Fig 2.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a model for COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying durations of symptoms and viral shedding based on severity levels. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic individuals, those with mild symptoms, and those with severe symptoms. Critical cases have the possibility of either recovery or death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. Transmission within the population is determined by the probability β when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual. With an average of 20 contacts per day, a value of β = 0.016 results in a doubling time of approximately 4-6 days and an R0 of around 2.2-2.7. This value was calibrated to data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and
post_context: .These weightings of 10:2:2:1 were chosen to align with time-use surveys and studies on known contact types. When considering the default beta value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population, these weightings aim to reflect the distribution of transmission events among different contact layers. In the absence of interventions, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. The value of beta can be altered by interventions like physical distancing. Individual differences in disease severity, time spent in different disease states, and infectiousness are accounted for by variations in viral load. Studies have shown that viral load peaks around symptom onset, followed by a decline. Our model includes two stages of viral load: an early high stage lasting for a shorter duration and a longer low stage. By default, the viral load for each individual is determined by a negative binomial distribution. Viral load influences the per-contact transmission probability for an individual. The distribution of viral loads among individuals is depicted in Fig 2.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the user must adjust this parameter to align with local epidemic data, as detailed in Section 2.6.8. If a realistic network structure is considered (including households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the transmission rate β will vary depending on the type of contact. By default, transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were selected based on time-use surveys and previous studies, aiming for a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a uniformly mixed population. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, approximately 30% of transmission events occur via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. Interventions like physical distancing can adjust the value of β. Furthermore, individuals can vary in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness, with individual viral load used to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The daily viral load determines the adjustment of the per-contact transmission probability (β) for individuals each day. Fig 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the situation; proportions for Seattle are detailed in [25]. Research findings are inconclusive on whether transmission rates are lower when the infected individual shows no symptoms [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not lower, but there is a parameter that can be altered as needed based on the specific modeling scenario or context, with some studies suggesting much lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
